popupSettingsDataManagementLocalStorageT: In order to save space on your local device, you can offload all your files to our encrypted backup node. The files will be loaded back when you open them.

In order to save space on this device, you can remove all your files. Be careful: your client is in local-only mode, and data is not backing up to external nodes. Ensure that your files are synced to your other devices before removing them.

popupSettingsMembershipSlide0Text: As a valued member your voice matters! Engage in exclusive events, shape strategic choices, and influence our roadmap.
popupSettingsMembershipSlide1Text: Members enjoy higher backup storage & sync limits, invitations for multiple guests to collaborate in shared spaces, and a unique identity on the Anytype Network.

popupConfirmLostPhraseTextWindows:
We understand how important your key is, but Anytype doesn't store a copy of it. Your key was generated on the device and automatically saved in your Windows Credential Manager. Follow these steps to recover it:

  • Open the Control Panel and change the "View by" option to "Large icons".
  • Locate and open the "Credential Manager" application.
  • Click on the "Windows Credentials" tab to view your saved credentials.
  • Search for the entry related to Anytype and click "Edit" to see details.
popupConfirmLostPhraseTextLinux:
We understand how important your key is, but Anytype doesn't store a copy of it. Your key was generated on the device and automatically saved in your Linux Keyring. Follow these steps to recover it:

  • Open the "Passwords and Keys" application, which you can find in the Utilities folder.
  • In the "Passwords and Keys" window, select the "Default" keyring on the left.
  • Search for the entry related to Anytype and double-click on it.
  • Click on the key icon to reveal the key, or select the "Copy" option to copy the key.

Copy the key and secure it safely.
popupConfirmLostPhraseTextMac:
We understand how important your key is, but Anytype doesn't store a copy of it. Your key was generated on the device and automatically saved in your macOS Keychain Access. Follow these steps to recover it:

  • Open the Keychain Access application, which you can find in the Utilities folder.
  • In the Keychain Access window, select "Login" from the list of Keychains on the left.
  • Click on the "Passwords" tab to view your saved passwords.
  • Search for the entry related to Anytype and double-click on it.
  • Check the "Show password" box, and your key will be displayed.

Copy the key and secure it safely.

You're now using the new & improved version of Anytype.

popupMigrationOnboardingText2: The updated version of Anytype on iOS and Android is also available for download! If you haven't already, please scan this QR code to update your devices:
popupMigrationOnboardingText3: We're excited to hear your feedback about the new features.
popupMigrationImportText1: Please take a few moments to check that your data has been imported correctly.
popupMigrationImportText2: One last thing. The updated version of Anytype on iOS and Android is also available for download! If you haven't already, please scan this QR code to update your devices:
popupMigrationImportText3: In case of any issues, you can repeat the migration process using the legacy desktop app or visit our community forum.
popupPhraseLabel1: It is represented by a recovery phrase ‚Äì 12 random words from which your vault is magically generated on this device.
popupPhraseLabel2: Whomever knows the combination of these words owns your vault. Right now, you are the only person in the world who knows it.
popupPhraseLabel3: All computational resources on Earth are not enough to break in. If you lose it, it cannot be recovered. So, store it somewhere safe!
popupPhraseLabel4: The easiest way to store your Key is to save it in your password manager.
popupPhraseLabel5: The most secure way is to write it down on paper and keep it offline, in a safe and secure place.

onboardingMainGraph11: Space is essentially a graph, and Anytype aims to provide a natural way of thinking where everything is represented as objects with specific relationships, just like in the real world.
onboardingMainSet11: Anytype has two basic formats: Sets and Collections. As in computer science, a Set is a data structure that contains only unique elements, while a Collection is any group of objects that are stored together. You can convert any set into a collection, but not the other way around.
onboardingMainSet21: Sets contain no duplicates and can be used to filter specific objects or relation types, such as all my bookmarks. Collections, however, can contain duplicates and are used for more general-purpose data storage; they can store anything.
onboardingMainSet31: View sets or collections as an entire object, or place them inline in documents. The first column will contain the collecting objects, and the others will show their relations.
onboardingMainSet32: Filter and adjust objects by any relation, such as today's notes (filter by date) or project documents (filter by project).
onboardingStoreType11: This Library contains all types of Objects and Relations. It comes with preinstalled types, as well as types that can be uploaded to Anytype for different use cases.
onboardingStoreType21: You can create your own types with any object layout for your own purposes. Additionally, you can save any existing object as a Library template if you need to use it frequently.
onboardingStoreType22: Now, let‚Äôs take a look at the Relations menu.
onboardingStoreRelation11: Relations are reusable links with meaning. Here you can see some examples of Relations, but the idea is that you can create your own Relations which are valuable to you and connect the Objects through them.
onboardingStoreRelation21: Establishing Relations helps you to understand the graph and its structure better. You can also create Collections or Sets based on the relationships for quick access.
onboardingObjectCreationStart11: Let‚Äôs create an object from scratch. The default object type is now ‚ÄòNote‚Äô, meaning that each new object is referred to as a Note unless you choose a different type. You can change the default object type anytime in the settings menu.
onboardingObjectCreationStart21: Choose here from the most popular object types, such as Page, Task, or Collection. You can also select an object from the Type menu, which shows all object types installed from the Library.
onboardingObjectCreationFinish11: For the Object you created, you can adjust it using the top menu. Change the cover, layout, or set up a relations to build the graph.
onboardingDashboard1Title: Let's start by quickly exploring Anytype's key features.

notificationImportSuccessText: You can find the imported objects in the selected space.
notificationImportErrorText: Sorry, but something went wrong during the import. Please try again, and let us know if it doesn't work.
notificationExportSuccessText: You can find the exported objects in the folder you selected.

notificationGallerySuccessText: Experience was successfully installed to the '%s' space. You can now open and start using it.

notificationApproveSuccessText: Your request to join '%s' space has been approved with %s access rights. The space will be available in your vault soon.
notificationRemoveSuccessText: You were removed from '%s' space, or the space has been deleted by the owner
notificationDeclineSuccessText: Your request to join the '%s' space has been declined.
notificationPermissionSuccessText: Your access rights were changed to '%s' in the '%s' space.
challengeTitle: Please enter the following numbers in the extension
networkMode0Text: Back up to the network managed by Anytype
networkMode1Text: Don't back up; sync within local network
networkMode2Text: Back up to your self-hosted network
